importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The research voyage by CSIRO scientists began in late 2022, marking the start of significant deep-sea exploration in the Gascoyne Marine Park.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from late 2022 to early 2025 encompasses the discovery and ongoing scientific analysis of new deep-sea species, highlighting a sustained effort in marine biodiversity research.

keyTakeAways: Scientists from Australia's CSIRO discovered two new species in the deep sea: a semi-transparent porcelain crab about 1.5cm long and a tiny lantern shark known as the West Australian Lantern Shark, growing up to 40cm.
The porcelain crab, found at a depth of about 122 meters, uses hair-like structures to filter plankton instead of claws, a unique feeding adaptation.
The West Australian Lantern Shark, discovered over 600 meters below sea level, is bioluminescent, with glowing photophores on its belly and flanks, a trait common in lantern sharks.
These discoveries were made during a research voyage in the Gascoyne Marine Park, located about 20km off the coast of Western Australia.
Australia is a global biodiversity hotspot, housing over a million species, many of which remain unexplored due to the vast, deep-sea regions still uncharted.

The voyage has resulted in the identification of approximately 20 new species, with scientists estimating that around 600 more may remain to be described and named due to the time-intensive process of verification and classification.
Dr. Will White, a fish scientist, and Dr. Andrew Hosie, curator of aquatic zoology, provided expert commentary on the biological features and ecological significance of the new species.

summaryOfNewsArticle: In late 2022, Australian scientists from CSIRO conducted a deep-sea research expedition in the Gascoyne Marine Park, off the coast of Western Australia, leading to the discovery of at least 20 new species, including a semi-transparent porcelain crab (1.5cm long) that filters plankton with hair-like structures and a glowing West Australian Lantern Shark (up to 40cm) found over 600 meters below the surface. These findings highlight Australia's role as a global biodiversity hotspot and emphasize the vast amount of unexplored marine life, with scientists estimating that around 600 more species may remain to be described. The discoveries offer insights into unique biological adaptations such as bioluminescence and specialized feeding mechanisms, underscoring the importance of deep-sea exploration and marine conservation.
title: Australia: Almond-sized crab and tiny lantern shark discovered in deep seas
